Citigroup downgrade Nano.$Nanofilm(MZH.SI)Citi downgrades Nanofilm to 'sell' as it sees a 'challenging path ahead' for the groupCiti Research analyst Jame Osman has downgraded his recommendation on Nanofilm Technologies to â€œsellâ€ from â€œbuyâ€ previously.In his Nov 3 report  Osman explains that the downgrade comes due to two key factors.First  the analyst expects the deceleration in Nanofilmâ€™s topline momentum to persist in the near-term. Uncertainty over the trajectory of a recovery in the industryâ€™s value chain also poses a key downside risk  he explains.â€œThe deceleration in Nanoâ€™s revenue growth (at 10% y-o-y for the 9MFY2022 ended Sept 30) was concerning to us particularly given the comparatively low base in 3QFY2021 due to previous supply chain delays pushing out FY2021â€™s seasonal peak production into 1QFY2022 â€ Osman notes.He adds: â€œManagement attributed the 3QFY2022 weakness to value chain disruption in China  including key FATP players such as Foxconn. Management expects this to persist into 4QFY2022  while an eventual recovery may be predicated on its key Customer Zâ€™s supply chain strategies in China going forward.â€â€œThis poses downside risk to current expectations for Nanofilm given its significant production exposure in Shanghai  in our view â€ he continues.Second  Nanofilmâ€™s plans to scale up its production capacity across several markets are likely to mean front-loaded gestation costs. The costs are also likely to put pressure on the groupâ€™s margins. At the same time  revenue contribution from Nanofilmâ€™s potential new customers will contribute meaningfully only from FY2024 onwards.On this  the analyst has cut his earnings per share (EPS) estimates for the FY2022 to FY2024 by 8% to 18%. The lower EPS estimates are mainly to factor in lower revenue growth as well as lower margin assumptions.Osman has also raised his weighted average cost of capital (WACC) assumption to 8.3% (from 7.5%) factoring a higher risk-free rate of 3.5%. His terminal growth rate assumption is also lowered to 2.0%.On this  the analyst has slashed his target price to $1.55 from $3.18.â€œDespite the 54% year-to-date (ytd) share price decline (versus the Straits Times Indexâ€™s 3% decline)  we now anticipate further headwinds ahead driven by an uncertain demand recovery as well as margin pressure from capacity expansion plans â€ he writes.â€œIn our bear case scenario  we see a further 47% downside from current levels [of $1.79 as at Nov 2] â€ he adds. â€œOur revised target price and FY2023 EPS imply a P/E ratio of 14x versus [an] EPS compound annual growth rate or CAGR of 8% over the FY2022-FY2024.â€
